document.docAuthor: Neretina, Anna N. & Kirdyasheva, Anna G.
document.masterDocTitle: A redescription of Moina australiensis Sars, 1896 (Cladocera: Moinidae) with short notes on Australian moinids

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A redescription of Moina australiensis Sars, 1896 (Cladocera: Moinidae) with short notes on Australian moinids

bibRefCitation.author: Sars, G. O.
bibRefCitation.refString: Sars, G. O. (1896) On fresh-water Entomostraca from the neighbourhood of Sydney, partly raised from dried mud. Archiv for Mathematik og Naturvidenskab, 18 (3), 1 - 81.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Moina australiensis Sars 1896 : p. 18
–24, pl. 3, fig. 1–11.

Moina australiensis in Brehm 1953 : p. 6
–9, fig. 2a–e.

Moina australiensis in Goulden 1968 : p. 48
–51, fig. 21a–j.
Etymology. Sars named this species in honor of Australia , the continent where it was found ( Sars 1896 ).

Type locality.
Sydney , New South Wales , Australia ( Sars 1896 )
.

Type material.
Potential author’s type material is kept at Zoological Museum , Oslo , Norway (GOS F 19249 and 19250)
.

Material examined from terra typica ,
Australia .
Over 100 parthenogenetic females, 50 ephippial females and 20 males from a pond ( S36.365645° , E148.934131° ) near Carrolls Lake , limnetic,
10 km E Berridale
, New South Wales , Australia , coll.
13.05.1975
by B. V . Timms, NNS-1997-217; over 100 parthenogenetic females, 50 ephippial females and 30 males from Boundary Lake ( S36.538924° , E149.119192° ),
18 km W Nimmitabel
, near Cooma , Monaro Table land, New South Wales , Australia , coll.
14.05.1975
by B. V . Timms, NNS-1997-223.

Short diagnosis. Species of large size for the genus (length of adult parthenogenetic female up to 1.30 mm ). Parthenogenetic female with body typical for the genus. Head and valves covered by fine hairs. Head without rostrum and head pore, ocellus absent. On inner side of valve, setulae near ventral setae are grouped into prominent bunches. Preanal and postanal margins of postabdomen covered by fine, relatively long hairs. Lateral side of postabdomen with a row of denticles decreasing in size towards tip. Antenna I relatively thick, its length almost five diameters of base. Structure of antenna II, maxilla I and thoracic limbs as for the genus. Ephippium darkbrownish, containing two resting eggs. Its dorsal chitinous plate wrinkled. Macrosculpture of ephippium represented by protruding knobs, some of them rugged. Male with elongated body. Gonopore opening in ventral surface of postabdomen near base of claws. Antenna I long, with four bisegmented hooks of similar size. Thoracic limb I with a long exopodite. Stiff seta 1 of male limb I having more thick basal segment than in female.

Redescription. Parthenogenetic female ( Figs. 1 A–F, 2A–K, 3A–I, 4A–G, 5A–I, 11A–B). General . In lateral view, body broadly ovoid ( Fig. 1A ) or subovoid ( Fig. 1B ), maximum height in body middle (body height/length ratio about 0.85 in adults). Body shape may vary significantly due to increasing of brood pouch volume during development of embryos ( Figs. 1 A–B). Dorsal margin convex, with a deep depression between head and valves. Posterodorsal angle broadly rounded, posteroventral angle well visible, triangular. Anteroventral angle broadly rounded ( Figs. 1 A–B). Fine short hairs on head and valves ( Figs. 1A, C , 4B ).

Head ( Figs. 1 A–D, 4A, 11A) relatively large, broadly ovoid in lateral view ( Figs. 1 A–C, 4A), without a rostrum, and with a distinct supraocular depression ( Fig. 1A , 11A ). No ocellus near base of antenna I ( Figs. 1 A–C, 11A). A shallow dorsolateral depression in posterior portion of head. Lateral, dorsal and frontal head pore absent. Dorsal and lateral surfaces of head covered by fine short hairs ( Figs. 1A, C , 11A ).
Labrum ( Figs. 1 E–F) with fleshy main body, its ventral margin convex, labral plate densely setulated.

Valves ( Figs. 1 A–B) large, broadly ovoid. Ventral margin of valve broadly rounded, convex, with short setae, decreasing in size posteriorly ( Figs. 2 A–B, 3A–B). Posterior portion of ventral margin with a row of fine, exactly marginal setules ( Figs. 3 B–D, 4C–F). Armature of this portion is significantly different in the different regions ( Fig. 4C ). Bunches of setulae adjoin to ventral setae ( Figs. 2 B–C, 3B–C, 4D–E, 11B); posterior setule in each bunch especially thick and long ( Figs. 4 D–E). Setulae located closer to the dorsal margin subequal in thickness, decreasing in length posteriorly ( Figs. 2D , 3D , 4F ). A setulated spine on inner face of valve near posteroventral angle ( Figs. 2E , 3E , 4G ). On outer surface valves show prominent sculpture represented by elongated polygons ( Figs. 4B ) and fine short hairs.
Thorax ( Figs. 1 A–B) long; abdomen relatively short.

Postabdomen ( Fig. 2F ) triangular, elongated, conically narrowing distally. Postabdomen length/height ratio about 2.8. Ventral margin almost straight, covered by rows of fine setulae ( Figs. 2 F–G, 3F). Anus located almost in middle of postabdomen. Preanal margin long, broadly convex ( Fig. 2F ), covered by fine relatively long hairs. Anal margin almost straight, almost two times shorter than postanal margin. Preanal and postanal angles smooth. Postanal margin covered by bunches of fine hairs ( Figs. 2 F–G, 3F). Basis of claws not inflated ( Figs. 2 F–G, 3F–G). In lateral face, postanal margin bears a large bident tooth (its branches always unequal in length) and a row of 11– 13 large, triangular plumose teeth ( Figs. 2 F–G, 3F).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, parthenogenetic female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A–B, adult parthenogenetic females, lateral view. C, head, lateral view. D, head, ventral view. E, labrum, lateral view. F, labrum, anterior view. Scale bars 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Postabdominal seta ( Fig. 2F ) long, subequal in length to postabdomen; its distal segment covered by fine hairs.

Postabdominal claw ( Figs. 2G , 3F ) robust, long (almost subequal in length than postanal margin), slightly curved, with particularly sharp tip. Its outer lateral side with a row of denticles decreasing in size towards tip. Prominent group of larger denticles near base of claw. Ventral margin of claw with about several denticles in its basal portion.

Antenna I ( Figs. 2H ) almost cylindrical, covered by concentric rows of minute denticles and fine long hairs. Antennular sensory seta slender, arising somewhat proximally to middle of antennular body on its lateral face. Nine short aesthetascs subequal in length.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, parthenogenetic female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, anterior portion of valve. B–C, posteroventral portions of valve. D, posterior portion of valve. E, setulated hooks on posteriormost portions of valves. F, postabdomen, lateral view. G, distal portion of postabdomen, lateral view. H, antenna I. I–J, antenna II. K, maxilla I. Scale bars 0.1 mm for A–D, F–J, 0.05 mm for E, K.

subSubSection.paragraph: Maxilla I ( Fig. 2K ) with three long densely setulated setae.
Thoracic limbs ( Figs. 3 H–I, 5A–I): five pairs.

Limb I ( Figs. 3 H–I, 5A) with elongated corm, inner distal lobe, or endite 5 (sensu Kotov 2013), with a single anterior seta ( Fig. 5A : 1), bearing short setulae, and two soft setae ( Fig. 5A : a, b). Armature of posterior soft setae similar in all limbs: both their segments armed with fine, long setulae ( Fig. 5A : a–h). Endite 4 with a single, relatively short anterior seta ( Fig. 5A : 2), and a single posterior seta ( Fig. 5A : c). Endite 3 with two posterior setae ( Fig. 5A : d–e), without anterior setae. Endite 2 with three posterior setae ( Fig. 5A : f–h). Two ejector hooks of remarkably different size. No maxillar process (endite 1) on limb base.

Limb II ( Figs. 5 B–E) with ovoid epipodite, limb distal portion as a large lobe bearing a large soft seta and a small lateral seta ( Fig. 5B ); three endites bearing four soft posterior setae ( Figs 5B : e5–e3), and two small setae of unclear homology near gnathobase. Gnathobase with two clear rows of setae: four anterior setae; a single long seta ( Fig. 5C : 1) near the beating seta (marked via arrows without number on Figs. 5 B–C) and two setae in the basal corner of the gnathobase ( Figs. 5C, D : 2–3), increasing in size distally; and nineteen posterior setae ( Figs. 5 B–C, E: a–s) of the gnathobase “filter plate”.

Limb III ( Figs. 5 F–G) with setulated preepipodite and ovoid epipodite. Exopodite large, ovoid, bearing four distal and two lateral setae ( Fig. 5F ). Inner distal portion of limb with three endites: endite 3 with a single anterior ( Fig. 5G : a) and a single posterior seta ( Fig. 5G : 1); endite 2 with single anterior ( Fig. 5G : 2) and two posterior setae ( Fig. 5G : b–c); endite 1 with a single short anterior ( Fig. 5G : 3) and four posterior setae ( Fig. 5G : d–g). Long anterior seta ( Fig. 5G : 4) located in the distal corner. All other parts of limb inner margin represent a single large lobe (probably this is a gnathobase (Kotov 2013)), bearing numerous setae ( Fig. 5G : endite 5).

Limb IV ( Fig. 5H ) smaller than limb III. Exopodite, similar to that in limb III, also bearing four distal and two lateral setae. Inner distal portion of this limb with two endites: endite 2 with an anterior seta ( Fig. 5H : 1) and a posterior seta ( Fig. 5H : a); and endite 1 with an anterior seta ( Fig. 5H : 2) and two posterior setae ( Fig. 5H : b–c). The major portion of the limb inner margin is the gnathobase filter plate (Kotov 2013), consisting of numerous setae ( Fig. 5H : endite 5).

Limb V (
Fig. 5I
) with large ovoid epipodite. Exopodite broadly ovoid, provided with a long distal and a small apical seta. Inner limb portion as a flat, setulated subrectangular lobe; and two setae unequal in size (
Fig. 5I
: 1, 2).

Ephippial female ( Figs. 6A , 7A , 8 A–H, 9A–E).
General body shape and appendages of ephippial female appearing similar to those of parthenogenetic female ( Figs. 8 A–D), but with dorsal portion modified into ephippium, containing two resting eggs (e.g. Fig. 6A ). Dorsal part of valves with reinforced dorsal wrinkled chitinous plate ( Figs. 7A , 8E , 9 A–E). In dorsal view, this plate has the same thickness almost all over the ephippium ( Fig. 9B ). Ephippium (after formaldehyde fixation, living animals were not investigated by us) darkbrownish ( Fig. 7A ). Macrosculpture of ephippium represented by protruding knobs, well-recognizable both under light ( Figs. 6A , 7A ) and scanning electron (8E–H, 9A–E) microscopes; such knobs near anterior, ventral and posterior portions of ephippium significantly lower than in the central portion ( Figs 8E, H , 9 A–C). Microsculpture as tiny irregular wrinkles on knobs, visible only under scanning electron microscope ( Figs. 8 F–H, 9D–E).

Male ( Figs. 6 B–K, 7B–D, 10A–C). General. In lateral view body ovoid, more elongated as compared to female (body height/length about 0.56) ( Fig. 6B ). Dorsal margin of valves slightly elevated above head, posteroventral angle distinct ( Fig. 6B ).
Head ( Figs. 6 B–D) more elongated than in female. Labrum similar to females, with large, setulated distal labral plate ( Figs. 6 E–F). Head pores absent. Compound eye large. Ocellus absent.
Thorax ( Fig. 6B ) relatively long.
Abdomen ( Fig. 6B ) short.

Postabdomen ( Figs. 6 H–I) generally as in female, with a large bident tooth distally (distal branch always significantly large than proximal branch), and row of about 9–11 large, triangular plumose teeth ( Figs. 6 H–J). Gonopores open in ventral surface of postabdomen near base of claws ( Figs. 6 H–J).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, parthenogenetic female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, anterior portion of valve. B–D, posteroventral portions of valve. E, setulated hooks on posteriormost portions of valves. F, distal portion of postabdomen, lateral view. G, distal portion of postabdomen, dorsal view. H, limb I. I, Stiff setae of limb I. Scale bars 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 4 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, parthenogenetic female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, head, lateral view. B, anterior portion of valve. C, valve, inner view. D–E, posteroventral portions of valve. F, posterior portion of valve. G, setulated hook on posteriormost portions of valve. Scale bars 0.2 mm for A, C, 0.1 mm for B, 0.0 5 mm for D–E, 0.02 mm for F–G.

FIGURE 5 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, parthenogenetic female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, limb I. B, limb II. C–E, gnatobase of limb II. F, limb III. G, inner distal portion of limb III. H, limb IV. I, limb V. Scale bars 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 6 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, ephippial female and adult male from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, ephippial female. B–H, adult male. A, ephippial female, lateral view. B, adult male, lateral view. C, head, lateral view. D, head, ventral view. E, labrum, lateral view. F, labrum, anterior view. G, posteroventral portion of valve. H, postabdomen, lateral view. I–J, distal portion of postabdomen, lateral view. K, distal portion of antenna I. Scale bars 0.1 mm for A–F, H–K, 0.05 mm for G.

subSubSection.paragraph: Antenna I ( Figs. 6 C–D) very long and regularly curved, covered by tiny hairs and rows of small denticles ( Figs. 6 C–D). Antennular sensory seta long, arising from first quarter of antennular body. Male seta more robust, located near sensory seta. Apical tip of antennular body separated into two parts: first one with nine short aesthetascs ( Figs. 6 C–D, K, 7B–C, D), second one with four bicuspid hooks ( Figs. 6 C–D, K, 7B–C, D).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, ephippial female and adult male from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, ephippium, dorsal view. B–D, antenna I of adult male, distal portion. Scale bars 0.1 mm for A, 0.05 mm for B–D.

subSubSection.paragraph: Limb I ( Figs. 10 A–C) essentially similar to parthenogenetic female, but with large, curved copulatory hook ( Figs. 10 A–B) and long exopodite ( Figs. 10 A–C). Exopodite bisegmented, with proximal portion covered by fine relatively long hairs and distal portions with small fine denticles ( Fig. 10C ). Stiff seta 1 ( Figs. 10 A–B) has the basal segment thicker than in females.
Size. Adult parthenogenetic females up to 1.30 mm in length; ephippial females up to 1.10 mm in length; adult males up to 0.80 mm in length.
Variability. No significant variability between investigated populations was found.

Taxonomic remarks. Among Australian moinids, only
Moina tenuicornis Sars, 1896
may be considered as a congener of
M. australiensis
( Figs. 11 A–F). Both species share some fine, but very consistent morphological features (see detailed comparison in Goulden (1968) and Smirnov (1976)) , among them: (1) lack of a dorsal head pore ( Figs. 11A, C ); (2) distal portion of postanal margin with bunches of fine hairs ( Figs. 2F, G , 3F , 8B , 11 D–E); (3) ephippium with two resting eggs. But they reliably differ from each other in: (1) proportions of antenna I and (2) structure of inner margin of valves.
M. australiensis
has a relatively short antenna I, with a length reaching almost five diameters of the base ( Figs. 11A ), while
M. tenuicornis
has elongated antenna I, with a length reaching eight diameters of base ( Figs. 11C ). In
M. australiensis
setulae near ventral setae are grouped into bunches ( Fig. 11B ), while in
M. tenuicornis
these setulae form a uniform row ( Fig. 11F ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, ephippial female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, postabdomen, lateral view. B, postabdomen, dorsal view. C, distal portion of postabdomen, lateral view. D, antenna I. E, ephippium, lateral view. F, fragment of ephippium, central portion. G, fragment of ephippium, central portion with higher magnification. H, posterior portion of ephippium. Scale bars 0.2 mm for E, 0.1 mm for A–B, D, G–H, 0.05 mm for C, F.

FIGURE 9 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, ephippial female from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A, ephippial female, dorsal view. B, ephippium on higher magnification, dorsal view C, anterior portion of ephippium. D–E, fragment of ephippium, central portion on higher magnifications. Scale bars 0.5 mm for A, 0.2 mm for B–C, 0.1 mm for D, 0.05 mm for E.

FIGURE 10 .
Moina australiensis Sars, 1896
, adult male from a pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia. A–C, limb I. Scale bars 0.1 mm.

FIGURE 11 . Comparison of parthenogenetic females of
Moina
australiensis
Sars, 1896
(A–B) (pond near Carrolls Lake, New South Wales, Australia) and
Moina tenuicornis Sars, 1896
(C–F) (Wellington, New Zealand). A, C, heads, lateral view. B, F, posteroventral portions of valves. D, postabdomen, lateral view. E, distal portion of postabdomen, lateral view. Scale bars 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ecology and distribution.
M. australiensis
was found to date in brackish water lakes with low turbidity ( Timms 1993 ) and flooded rock holes with a broad range of physicochemical characteristics (
Bayly et al . 2011
). At the same time,
M. tenuicornis
was found in sewage ponds ( Wellington , New Zealand ), characterized by slightly alkaline water, dissolved oxygen concentration more than of 6 mg /liter and high concentrations of organic substances ( Vidal 1973 ). Relatively similar conditions plus especially high turbidity were reported by
Shiel et al . (1982)
. Probably, these two species differ in their ecological requirements, but further investigations are required on their preferences. Except for Vidal (1973) , other publications with detailed descriptions of ecological conditions do not contain figures or microphotographs of investigated populations (
Shiel et al . 1982
; Timms 1993 , 1997 ;
Bayly et al . 2011
) and we could not check accurateness of author’s identification.

According to Goulden (1968) and Smirnov (1976) , distribution ranges of
M. australiensis
and
M. tenuicornis
are mainly restricted to Australia . There are no reliable data on occurrence of these taxa in other parts of Australasia or in the Oriental zone. Sars’ record of
M. tenuicornis
in South Africa ( Sars 1916 : pl. XXXV 2, 2a, 2b, 2c) seems doubtful in the frame of the continental endemism concept ( Frey 1982 ), although a specimen illustrated by him has a relatively long antenna I ( Sars 1916: pl. XXXV 2, 2a ). Some other authors have recorded
M. tenuicornis
in Africa (e.g. Smirnov 1976 ; Clarke & Rayner 1999 ;
Seaman et al . 1999
). They pictured specimens with a relatively long antenna I as well (e.g.
Seaman et al . 1999
: fig. 4.8.: p), but, unfortunately, their descriptions lack data on the head pores, armature of valve, structure of distal portion of postanal margin and ephippium ornamentation.
